title: 107_hr2252
content: The Act titled "Conduit Contribution Prevention Act of 2001" increases penalties for violations of conduit contribution ban. The Act "Conduit Contribution Prevention Act of 2001" increases civil and criminal penalties for knowing and willful violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Civil penalties are increased to not less than 300 percent of the amount involved in the violation and not more than the greater of $50,000 or 1000 percent of the amount involved. Criminal penalties are also increased. The Act "Conduit Contribution Prevention Act of 2001" increases civil and criminal penalties for violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. For violations involving $1,000 or more in a calendar year, fines will be not less than 300 percent of the amount involved and not more than $50,000 or 1000 percent of the amount. Additionally, imprisonment for up to 2 years is possible. The United States Sentencing Commission is required to create guidelines for penalties related to violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, including considering the amount involved. The United States Sentencing Commission must establish penalties for violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, taking into account the contribution amount. The guideline must be issued within 90 days of the enactment of the Act, following the procedures of the Sentencing Reform Act of 1987. The amendments made by this section relate to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, including mandatory referral to the Attorney General for violations of section 320 and extending the statute of limitations to 5 years for such violations. The amendments made by this section extend the statute of limitations to 3 years (or 5 years for violations of section 320) and apply to violations occurring after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3 extends the ban on foreign contributions to all campaign-related disbursements, including those to political committees and for independent expenditures. The amendments apply to disbursements made after the enactment of this Act.
